awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Expansion/Contraction of the Intertropical Convergence Zone; An Emerging Mechanism of Tropical Precipitation Changes for Reinterpreting Paleoclimate
awd_abstract_narration:
The spatial distribution of tropical precipitation is determined by the average location and seasonal march of the intertropical convergence zone (ITCZ). The latitudinal shift of the ITCZ is typically employed as the go-to theory for interpreting past hydroclimate changes and defining mechanisms of the response to climate forcing (past and future). 

This project, however, is based on the premise that the simultaneous contraction and intensification (CI) of the ITCZ is a far more powerful mode of tropical precipitation changes (by a factor of 4) in response to both paleoclimate and anthropogenic forcing than the more commonly employed ITCZ shift.

The overarching goal of the project is to couple reconstructions of past changes in the CI mode from paleoclimate proxy records with a dynamical framework of the CI mode to constrain future tropical precipitation changes and variability. This specific aims are to: i) explore the dynamics of the CI mode to identify the mechanisms that lead to the direction of changes seen in simulations of past and future climate as well as evaluate the uncertainties in these processes and ii) use the emerging knowledge of the CI mode to reinterpret the paleoclimate record to constrain the past behavior of ITCZ shifts versus CI. 

The project would help develop a deeper understanding of the ITCZ and potentially improve the ability of climate models to forecast broad-scale future changes (and variability) in the magnitude and spatial structure topical precipitation.  The project would also support two early career scientists and leverage existing public outreach programs in science at the University of Washington and the University of California-Berkeley.

por.por_cntn:
The Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) is characterized by a heavy band of tropical rainfall that circumnavigates the globe. This essential feature of Earth’s climate system delineates the moist and bio-diverse deep tropics from the dry and barren subtropics and dictates the availability freshwater resources for ecosystems and billions of people around the globe. A large body of work has emerged over the past few decades demonstrating that this tropical rainband, when averaged across all longitudes, shifts north and south in response to heating or cooling the atmosphere in one hemisphere more than the other. Because of its utility in relating changes in tropical rainfall patterns to the global energy budget, this energetic framework of the ITCZ has been widely applied to study changing tropical rainfall patterns in past and future climate regimes using highly idealized and comprehensive climate models. This framework is also prevalent in studies of paleoclimate proxy records, whereby concurrent increases in rainfall in one latitude band and decreases in another latitude band are frequently interpreted in terms of a latitudinal shift of the ITCZ.

However, our work has demonstrated that the concept of a latitudinal shift of the zonal mean ITCZ only explains a very small fraction of simulated changes in tropical rainfall in a large collection of model simulations under paleoclimate and anthropogenic forcing. We present two alternative modes of ITCZ variability that explain a substantially greater fraction of the forced rainfall responses and found that a tight scaling exists between these two modes, namely simultaneous changes in the width and intensity of the ITCZ. We demonstrated that the ITCZ robustly contracts and intensifies under global warming associated with CO2 forcing and that it robustly expands and de-intensifies under global cooling associated with glacial climate states. We further demonstrated that the contraction of the ITCZ under global warming is due to a reduced seasonal migration of the ITCZ off the equator; the mechanism of this response is an increase in the efficiency of energy transport across the equator in the atmosphere which we speculate results from a rising tropopause and enhanced eddy moisture transport. Our results indicate that coordinated changes in the width and intensity of the ITCZ is a far more powerful mode of tropical precipitation changes than latitudinal shifts of the ITCZ and that knowledge of this new mode should be used to reinterpret the paleoclimate record.

Our results further indicate that even in simulations in which the tropical rainfall distribution shifts north or south (in response to forcings that heat or cool the atmosphere in one hemisphere more than the other such as extratropical volcanic eruptions and North Atlantic iceberg discharges), a latitudinal shift of the tropical rainband still poorly describes the simulated changes in tropical rainfall. Instead, the rainfall response is better represented by changes in the relative magnitude of the bi-modal precipitation peaks (i.e. the northern hemisphere and southern hemisphere rainfall peaks follow an inverse relationship in their intensity without changing their position). These results highlight the need to define an alternative mode of ITCZ variability in future work that captures the inverse relationship between the bi-modal precipitation peaks in the northern and southern hemisphere.

Lastly, we examined the longitudinal structure of tropical rainfall changes under paleoclimate and anthropogenic forcing. We found large longitudinal variations in the tropical rainfall response and that even the Pacific rainband doesn’t shift uniformly under any forcing considered. Under climate forcings with strong hemispheric asymmetry such as volcanic forcing and North Atlantic iceberg discharges, the zonal mean ITCZ shift was robust across models, but the direction and magnitude of the shift varied strongly as a function of longitude. While under forcings with weak hemispheric asymmetry such as CO2 and mid-Holocene forcing, zonal mean shifts of the ITCZ were small or absent, but the rainband did shift regionally in coherent ways across models. Our findings caution against inferring large-scale changes in the tropical rainband based on data from a limited spatial domain, such as typically found in paleoclimate proxy data.

Taken together, these findings advance our understanding of the character and mechanisms of tropical rainfall responses to anthropogenic and paleoclimatic forcings. As such, they can be used to more accurately interpret tropical rainfall patterns from the geologic record. In addition to advancing the disciplines of climate dynamics and paleoclimatology, improved understanding of tropical rainfall changes under global warming have implications that reach far outside of the physical sciences and have direct relevance to climate change impacts research on water resource management, ecology, and agriculture.
